ETV REPORTER
June 20. 1908
MARYLAND EDUCATIONAL OFFICIALS AGREED AT A RECENT CONFERENCE TO RECOM-
mend installation of TV antennas and distribution systems in all new school construction in
the state. At a two-day meeting called by Governor Spiro Agnew. educators from across the
state decided that this basic equipment should be a requirement for state approval of new
school facilities.
They proposed an immediate budgeting of funds for classroom TV receivers, and the develop¬
ment of a state purchasing plan which would assure the acquisition of compatible equipment in
large quantities to effect cost savings. The Superintendent of Schools' Committee on Admini¬
stration and Finance was given authority to assume responsibility for approving the coordinat¬
ed purchasing plan to be developed by the Maryland Educational-Cultural Broadcasting Com¬
mission. the Division of Instructional TV of the State Department of Education, and the
Department of Budget and Procurement.
The Broadcasting Commission's Engineering Division will assume responsibility for develop¬
ment of standard specifications for equipment to be installed in the schools. The conferees
also approved a recommendation calling for an amendment to the state aid formula which
would provide additional professional assistance to the school systems in coordinating TV
program planning and scheduling between teachers, schools, and the ETV network.
NEW FILMS. TELECOURSES AVAILABLE FROM —
Great Plains National Instructional Television Library. University of Nebraska. Lin¬
coln, Neb, 68508. "Approaching Poetryproduced by WNDT-TV, Educational Broadcasting
Corp., New York City, contains fifteen, 20-minute lessons and an optional 30-minute, in-
service program. The series is intended to help the classroom teacher present poetry to
those high school students who may never have been introduced to the subject. Pulitzer Prize-
winning poet Gwendolyn Brooks appears as an on-camera guest. Quad videotapes or a kine¬
scope of representative lessons from the series, and a sample copy of the accompanying
teacher's guide, may be obtained free, from the Greant Plains Library, which also has avail¬
able a series of sixty, half-hour videotaped lessons, entitled "TV High School. " designed for
non-high school graduates to prepare them for the national high school equivalency test. The
telecourse, produced by the Manpower Education Institute of New York City, is divided into
five required areas of instruction: English. Mathematics. Social Studies. Science and Litera¬
ture. Preview samplers on either quad videotape or kinescope, and sample Home Study Kits
may be obtained by contacting the Library.
THE FCC TOOK THE FOLLOWING ETV ACTIONS DURING THE PERIOD JUNE 12-25:
Received request from the Nebraska ETV Commission for assignment of call letters
KRNE-TV for new station in Merriman.
Accepted for filing applications by Boston Catholic TV Center. Inc. . Andover. Mass.,
for a CP for a new ITFS station in Wood Hill, Mass., and by Duke University. Durham. N. C.,
for a new ITFS station at the Duke Medical Center. Durham. Also accepted for filing an
application for a license to cover a CP for new station WVTB by the University of Vermont
and State Agricultural College, St. Johnsbury. Vt. , and an application to cover the modifica¬
tion of CP to extend the completion date for WETX by The Greater Washington Educational
Television Association. Inc., Washington, D.C.
Granted CPs for Translator stations to: Joaquin Sierra ETV Assn. . Mt. Bullion.
Calif.. for station on CL. 80 to rebroadcast KQED (Ch. 9) San Francisco, to serve Mariposa.
Cathey's Valley and Hornitos; for station on Ch. 12 to rebroadcast KQED to Coulterville and
Greely Hill; and for station on Ch. 6 to rebroadcast,KQED to Twain Harte and Belleview.
